title: 'Ole hasn't got his team yet... he hasn't got the players' says Man Utd assistant manager Phelan
text:
Manchester United's assistant manager Mike Phelan believes Ole Gunnar Solskjaer knows he needs to make significant investments to improve the playing squad to turn the club's dire fortunes around on the field.

Solskjaer spent around £140m in the summer to bring in the likes of Harry Maguire, Aaron Wan-Bissaka and Daniel James from Leicester City, Crystal Palace and Swansea respectively.

But that investment has not led to any sort of success with United languishing in 12th position ahead of the visit of rivals Liverpool.

Mike Phelan insists Ole Gunnar Solskjaer knows he needs to spend to improve the squad

Harry Maguire was one of three summer signings as Manchester United spent around £140m

But Phelan insisted that the former United striker's appointment brought back a 'feel good factor' to the club - even if the players have 'bottomed out' since.

Phelan told The Sun: 'Ole hasn't got his team yet, he hasn't got the players. He's got three but you need more than three to be the manager of your own team.

'We were riding a crest of a wave and were flying. And all we did was subtle changes. We brought back a feel good factor.

But Solskjaer's side have struggled despite the signings and currently sit 12th in the table

'We got on with everybody made everybody smile, the players reacted really well.

'We wanted to bring something back that was Man United and all we did we told the players they were going to wear suits again for away games.

'It was as if we had brought something back that was part of the culture of the club and wearing the badge.

'It was subtle changes but they worked. We went off like a flyer and we dropped the same way but there were reasons for that.

Nevertheless Phelan has backed Solskjaer despite players 'bottoming out' after the initial high

'We took them from nothing to sky high, the fitness levels went through the roof but they bottomed out because it was just too much and they weren't prepared for it.'

Further financial investment in the playing squad would require the approval of Ed Woodward, who once again publicly backed Solskjaer by describing him as the walking, talking' version of the club's philosophy.

Recent reports have suggested United could sack Solskjaer should they suffer defeat in their clash with Liverpool, but Woodward has once again reiterated his belief that the Norwegian is the man to bring about the club's revival.
description: Manchester United assistant manager Mike Phelan has said Ole Gunnar Solskjaer knows that his squad requires further investment to turn the club's fortunes around on the field.
